questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have an app named App1 that uses data from two on-premises Microsoft SQL Server databases named DB1 and DB2.
You plan to move DB1 and DB2 to Azure.
You need to implement Azure services to host DB1 and DB2. The solution must support server-side transactions across DB1 and DB2.
Solution: You deploy DB1 and DB2 to SQL Server on an Azure virtual machine.
Does this meet the goal?
questions.answer_description:
Understanding distributed transactions.
When both the database management system and client are under the same ownership (e.g. when SQL Server is deployed to a virtual machine), transactions are available and the lock duration can be controlled.
Reference:
https://docs.particular.net/nservicebus/azure/understanding-transactionality-in-azure

discussion.content: The provided answer is correct

Answer A is correct

While server-side transactions are available for Azure SQL Managed Instances via Server Trust Groups as in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/elastic-transactions-overview, it only has partial support as in https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/managed-instance/transact-sql-tsql-differences-sql-server#distributed-transactions. So, the answer A for using SQL server on Azure VMs is correct considering the supportability. 

Microsoft's wording needs to be different on the docs as I feel. When they say "A server-side distributed transactions using Transact-SQL are available only for Azure SQL Managed Instance", they should mention that it is available only for Azure SQL Managed Instance with other Azure SQL products and features and full SQL Server on Azure VMs are not concerned.

In today's exam. Score 900+ 
Correct answer.
On exam 23 Dec 2021, I chose B. The correct answer is SQL managed instance and this was confirmed with my trainer before the exam.
On exam today 19/11/21. Score 860.
also managed instance supports across db transation
Yes. the answer is correct
SQL Server on Azure VM has full SQL features and coverage so answer is Yes
9th Aug 21 - Was in today's exam. 54 Questions in total (4 Case study), No Lab
26-June-21, Passed the exam. Answered - Yes

Answer is A.
Transactions are supported when the DBs are hosted on the same sql server. So, both the DBs needs to be hosted on the same SQL server.
repeated question #66

comments.content: you are right IF you want to use TransactSql. The same article also says:” the ability to coordinate distributed transactions has now been directly integrated into SQL Database or Managed Instance” so answer is A (yes)

discussion.content:
According to:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-sql/database/elastic-transactions-overview
"A server-side distributed transactions using Transact-SQL are available only for Azure SQL Managed Instance." so PaaS rather than IaaS, which would be answer B
why is this A. the provided url doesnt really answer this. They are referring to databases and not client/server transactions in the question.
correct answer - came in exam last week

comments.content: Why B? you provided same explanation for A, why B ?

discussion.content:
Answer : B

Explanation:
Instead deploy DB1 and DB2 to SQL Server on an Azure virtual machine.
Note: Understanding distributed transactions.
When both the database management system and client are under the same ownership (e.g. when SQL Server is deployed to a virtual machine), transactions are available and the lock duration can be controlled.
Reference:
https://docs.particular.net/nservicebus/azure/understanding-transactionality-in-azure

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have an Azure Cosmos DB database that contains a container named Container1. The partition key for Container1 is set to /day. Container1 contains the items shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to programmatically query Azure Cosmos DB and retrieve Item1 and Item2 only.
Solution: You run the following query.

SELECT id FROM c -
WHERE c.day = "Mon" OR c.day = "Tue"
You set the EnableCrossPartitionQuery property to False.
Does this meet the goal?
questions.answer_description:
Returns Item1 only as EnableCrossPartitionQuery property to False. If EnableCrossPartitionQuery property is set to true, it will return Item1, Item2, and Item3.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/sql-query-where https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.azure.documents.client.feedoptions.enablecrosspartitionquery?view=azure-dotnet

comments.content: This is absolutely true because if not then it should have returned item 1 and 2 not just item 1.

discussion.content: I think the answer is B but for a different reason than stated. It looks like if EnableCrossPartitionQuery is disabled and you try to query two partitions - Mon and Tue - then it would throw an exception and wouldn't return anything.
Was in today's exam. Given answer is correct.
In the exam on 12-03-2022. Total 50 questions including case study. "Litware Acquired Fabricam" case study.
On exam13dic2021

Answer is No

The query will look for day as Monday or Tuesday. Due to OR condition on day, query will span out to multiple partitions. Therefore,

This query will return Item1, Item2 and Item3.

comments.content: Cross partitions queries are disabled, so no you won't get anything because it states you need to do it programmatically and that will throw an exception when your result contains documents from multiple partitions.

discussion.content:
Something to note - CosmosDB SDK v3 (Microsoft.Azure.Cosmos) Cross Partition Queries are enabled by default and there is no option to enable/disable it with EnableCrossPartitionQuery. 
Instead you specify Partition Key - if partition key is provided, it will scan just 1 partition, if no partition key is provided it will scan all partitions.
9th Aug 21 - Was in today's exam. 54 Questions in total (4 Case study), No Lab
typo in query , select query needs to be c.id not id.

If the query includes a filter against the partition key, like SELECT * FROM c WHERE c.city = "Seattle", it is routed to a single partition

this query has two filters in partition key day, which will require for execution in 2 partitions at least. so EnableCrossPartitionQuery should be true

Since I didn't fully understand it myself, and the comments here also give mixed answers, I tested it myself. Created database exactly specified here and ran query with EnableCrossPartitionQuery disabled.

The query as stated in the question returns an error "Identifier 'id' could not be resolved".

After changing "id" to "c.id" in the query it works, but returns three results (as would be expected with EnableCrossPartitionQuery turned on).

I would guess that Cosmos DB creates partitions only when data exceeds a certain size? And despite the partition key here, Cosmos DB would use a single partition for these 4 small records?
Was on exam 3 July 2021 and correct
The answer is No because the query will throw an exception. It should be Select c.id.... not Select id.
Took exam today passed this morning was on there 6/21/2021
answer is B. for me its based on the query i would look for the item and not the day.
On exam 5/15/2021
answer suppose to be B because Key is Day and query is requesting for Iteam1/Item2 data with Enablecrosspratition is disabled hence it won't get Iteam 3. was in exam last week.
was in today's exam
Was in today's exam.

Answer is B. Reason syntax error, it should be c.id
Consider if c.id is there then answer is A.

comments.content: I don't think so, because we are passing Tue also c.day = "Tue". Even if the property is True/False- the answer will be B.

discussion.content: Yes, the answer is B, but the reason is different from what is mentioned. The required id output is Item1 and Item2. Both are on the day "Mon" which is a partition key. So irrespective of CrossPartition setting, the query should select only the items of "Mon" for getting the output of Item1 and Item2.
Just to be sure, the parting key is day so all the items are in the same parting. So the result would be Mon and Thu. So b would be the correct answer.

comments.content: No, only records with same value on partition key will be assigned to same logical partition. But answer is still B as per @Kasurot's explaination.

discussion.content: Should be A.YES, because item1 and item2 both n the same partition

questions.answer_description:
Within your template, the dependsOn element enables you to define one resource as a dependent on one or more resources. Its value can be a comma- separated list of resource names.
Box 1: 'Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces'
This resource is a virtual machine. It depends on two other resources:
Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts
Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces
Box 2: 'Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/'
The dependsOn element enables you to define one resource as a dependent on one or more resources. The resource depends on two other resources:
Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses
Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks

Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/resource-manager-tutorial-create-templates-with-dependent-resources
questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You plan to deploy an Azure virtual machine named VM1 by using an Azure Resource Manager template.
You need to complete the template.
What should you include in the template? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Given Answer is correct, to understand the dependency refers to the diagram.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/templates/media/template-tutorial-create-templates-with-dependent-resources/resource-manager-template-dependent-resources-diagram.png
given answer is correct.

"name": "[variables('networkInterfaceName')]",
parameters('virtualNetworkName'), parameters('subnetName'))]"
dependon element define the deployment order, so NIC need VNet deployed first. If Vnet deployed, then the subnet must be deployed already ~
Correct Answer - Appeared in today's exam 29 March 2022

Answer is correct.
The second answer dependency is virtual network but not the subnet.
see this github quickstart template shared by microsoft official
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/templates/microsoft.network/networkinterfaces?tabs=json#quickstart-templates
https://github.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/blob/master/quickstarts/microsoft.network/nic-publicip-dns-vnet/azuredeploy.json
On Exam today, 28-03-2022; Most of the questions from this site, very useful !!

For Network Interface dependency is with Subnet not virtual network directly. Tested from custom deployment in portal

"resources": [
 {
 "type": "Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces",
 "apiVersion": "2020-06-01",
 "name": "[variables('networkInterfaceName')]",
 "location": "[parameters('location')]",
 "dependsOn": [
 "[resourceId('Microsoft.Network/networkSecurityGroups', parameters('networkSecurityGroupName'))]",
 "[resourceId('Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses', variables('publicIPAddressName'))]",
 "[resourceId('Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/subnets', parameters('virtualNetworkName'), parameters('subnetName'))]"
 ]
Appeared today 19-2-2022.. Passed with 871.
Appeared today 13.2.2022
Appeared today 29.10.2021

1 - Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces/
2 - Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/

The dependsOn element enables you to define one resource as a dependent on one or more resources. Its value can be a comma- separated list of resource names.
Virtual machine is dependent on network interface
Network interface is dependent on virtual networks.

Answer is correct

Explanation
-------------------- 
Box 1 - Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces/
you can't create the virtual machine until its storage account and network interface exist. 

Box 2 - Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/
The resource type is Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces. The resource depends on two other resources:

Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses
Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks

Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/templates/template-tutorial-create-templates-with-dependent-resources?tabs=CLI
Given Answer is correct

comments.content: Were there any labs in the exam?

discussion.content: On Exam 6/14 . Answers are correct
On exam 5/15/2021
NetworkInterfaces - VirtualNetworks
In exam today

the network interface is tricky and the question dubious:
- PublicIP is not mandatory (not all VM needs public IP)
- The interface is assigned to a subnet and if you create a VM, and export the template the NIC shows the dependency on Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/subnets
was in exam today answered the same
Just my 5 cents here - logically you are not able to create VNET without subnet, so you should depent on VNET
In the Exam
https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/master/101-vm-simple-windows/azuredeploy.json
Was in today's exam

Answer seems to be correct.
Following link provided by BhargaV, we can find :

{
 "type": "Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces",
 "apiVersion": "2020-06-01",
 "name": "[variables('nicName')]",
 "location": "[parameters('location')]",
 "dependsOn": [
 "[resourceId('Microsoft.Network/publicIPAddresses', parameters('publicIPName'))]",
 "[resourceId('Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks', variables('virtualNetworkName'))]"
 ]

This was in my exam couple of days ago...I scored 8xx
I answered 

'Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces/' 
and 
'Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/'

comments.content:
I think you are wrong. Two examples in which the networkInterface directly depends on virtualNetworks:
https://github.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/blob/master/101-vm-simple-windows/azuredeploy.json
https://github.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/blob/master/101-vm-simple-linux/azuredeploy.json

The reason why those examples work is because the subnet is created as a dependent resource in the virtualNetworks object. In ARM templates, you can create subnets after a virtual network, and in that case the network interface would fail to create. The correct answer should be to have the network interface depend on the Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/subnets. The general rule is anything that uses the resourceId function, should have a dependsOn on that. In general, I think this question is a little vague. If they shared the virtualNetwork part of the ARM, then it would be clear.

discussion.content:
1.Microsoft.Network/networkInterfaces
2.Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/subnets

Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks/subnets depends on Microsoft.Network/virtualNetworks
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/windows/ps-template#create-a-virtual-machine
Was in today's exam.
In the exam this week

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have an Azure Cosmos DB database that contains a container named Container1. The partition key for Container1 is set to /day. Container1 contains the items shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You need to programmatically query Azure Cosmos DB and retrieve Item1 and Item2 only.
Solution: You run the following query.

SELECT day FROM c -
WHERE c.value = "10" OR c.value = "15"
You set the EnableCrossPartitionQuery property to True.
Does this meet the goal?
questions.answer_description:
Returns Item1, Item2, Item3, and Item4.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/sql-query-where

discussion.content: Yes, the answer is correct
In the exam on 12-03-2022. Total 50 questions including case study. "Litware Acquired Fabricam" case study.
syntax error. SELECT should always say c.column_name
The value is a reserved keyword in CosmosDB so the query will fail.
On exam 23 Dec 2021, I chose the same answer

The optional WHERE clause specifies condition(s) that the source JSON items must satisfy for the query to include them in results. A JSON item must evaluate the specified conditions to true to be considered for the result. This query will return Item1, Item2, Item3 and Item4.

Answer is No

comments.content: hello, kkstays can u please confirm me Practical labs LIKE (Azure portal question) include in exam or just M.C.Q based exam .waiting for your response. its highly appreciated.

discussion.content: 9th Aug 21 - Was in today's exam. 54 Questions in total (4 Case study), No Lab

The query is executable but will return all 4 items. So it's No
 If the query does not have a filter on partition key, then it is executed in all partitions, and results are merged client side. In this case, partition key is day which not in query

what will be returned if EnableCrossPartitionQuery property is set to False?

comments.content:
ground beef 


● minced beef - 800 g
● ground black pepper - ⅓ tsp.
● salt - 1 tsp.
● corn starch - 1 tbsp.
● paprika - 1 tsp.
● sour cream - 2 tbsp.
● milk - 100 ml
● egg - 1 pc.
● onion - 100 g


my guess is in addition to the syntax error, the query would return an error as you didn't include the partition id value in the query. This means c.day must be included in the SELECT query if you set EnableCrossPartitionQuery to False.

in other words, EnableCrossPartitionQuery must be set to true if you don't want to include the partition id in the query (essentially executing across more than one partition).


https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/sql-api-query-metrics

(interpreting the section where they explain the parameter EnableCrossPartitionQuery: 

Must be set to true for any query that requires to be executed across more than one partition. This is an explicit flag to enable you to make conscious performance tradeoffs during development time.)

discussion.content: s0850test123 is correct. The given query will provide a Syntax error. In either case though, if the syntax was correct, the query would return items 2, 2, 3, and 4. So the answer is B - No.

comments.content:
I agree with this. "Once aliased, the original source name cannot be bound. For example, SELECT Families.id FROM Families f is syntactically invalid because the identifier Families has been aliased and can't be resolved anymore.

All referenced properties must be fully qualified, to avoid any ambiguous bindings in the absence of strict schema adherence."

Over here, we can see that the container has not been aliased. So this logic does not apply. (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/sql-query-from)

discussion.content: I think the answer is correct because we are not using alias name for the container in the FROM clause. When there is an alias name there will be ambiguity.
I agree, the syntax for the query needs to be changed to 'Select *'

Answer should be NO
Correct options(syntax) :-
SELECT * FROM c OR SELECT c.id FROM c

Incorrect syntax
SELECT id FROM c

Answer is no. syntax error.

All referenced properties must be fully qualified, to avoid any ambiguous bindings in the absence of strict schema adherence. For example, SELECT id FROM Families f is syntactically invalid because the property id isn't bound.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/sql-query-from
B. Syntax error
Given answer is correct
